name: Coolest Cooler
failure_reason: Manufacturing costs exceeded the $165-$185 price charged to backers, resulting in losses on every unit. Over 20,000 backers never received their coolers before the company shut down in December 2019.

name: ZANO Drone
failure_reason: Company filed for liquidation in November 2015 after shipping only 600 barely functional units out of 15,000 orders. Promotional video was faked using a DJI Inspire drone. Over-ambitious stretch goals and financial mismanagement led to collapse.

name: CST-01: The World's Thinnest Watch
failure_reason: Manufacturing partner Flextronics withdrew support. Watch cost $260 to produce vs $129 pledge price. Only 80 units shipped before Central Standard Timing filed for bankruptcy with $30K assets against $891K liabilities.

name: OUYA
failure_reason: Console suffered from hardware defects (weak Wi-Fi, sticky controller buttons), poor game library, and shipped to retail before Kickstarter backers received theirs. Acquired by Razer in 2015, servers shut down June 2019.

name: Pebble Time
failure_reason: Company struggled with cash flow and competition from Apple Watch. Sold to Fitbit in December 2016 for $23M. Fitbit discontinued all Pebble hardware and services, abandoning backers of Pebble 2/Time 2/Core campaigns.

name: Tiko 3D Printer
failure_reason: Unsustainable economics with cost of goods at 60% of sale price. Unibody design required unreliable custom components. Only ~4,000 units shipped before company entered 'hibernation mode' in February 2017.

name: ZNAPS
failure_reason: Creators disappeared without shipping products to backers while simultaneously selling units through retail channels. Connected to serial scam team (Nbition/Chiu brothers) behind Arist and Toasteroid. No backer received their reward.

name: Amabrush
failure_reason: Unable to find manufacturers who could produce at viable price. Shipped ~4,000 defective units before filing bankruptcy on June 5, 2019 with 4.5M EUR debt against 524K EUR assets.

name: iBackPack
failure_reason: FTC confirmed fraud - creator Doug Monahan spent $800K+ from multiple campaigns on personal expenses and Bitcoin instead of production. Permanently banned from crowdfunding in 2019. No products delivered.

name: Peachy Printer
failure_reason: Co-founder David Boe embezzled CA$324,000 of Kickstarter funds to build personal house. Despite clever working prototype, project collapsed in 2017 after embezzlement exposed. No printers delivered to backers.

name: Pirate3D Buccaneer
failure_reason: Ran out of money after shipping only 40% of orders. Recent college graduates with no manufacturing experience couldn't handle production costs and $600 international shipping fees. Company officially walked away from project in 2016.

name: OSSIC X
failure_reason: Ran out of money after failing to secure Series A funding. Only 250 of 10,000+ units delivered before company shut down in May 2018. Filed Chapter 7 bankruptcy. VR market slowdown made investors unwilling to fund production.

name: Superbook
failure_reason: Ran out of money after shipping only 75% of orders. Component price increases, manufacturer problems, and alleged theft of $300K inventory by distributor King Oasis depleted funds. No refunds offered.

name: Zim 3D Printer
failure_reason: Company collapsed in July 2015 after CEO was critically injured in car accident. Other founders left, all support and shipping ceased. Printer required heavy support but was closed-source, leaving backers stranded.

name: Bragi Dash
failure_reason: Despite delivering products, company struggled with hardware development issues and poor Bluetooth pairing. Unable to compete with Apple AirPods, Bragi sold its entire hardware business in April 2019 and pivoted to software-only.

name: Arist Coffee Maker
failure_reason: Creators disappeared after multiple missed shipping deadlines. Connected to serial scam team (Nbition/Chiu brothers) behind ZNAPS and Toasteroid. Prototype was allegedly just a Jura coffee machine. Launch party attendees were paid actors given cash refunds.

name: ZionEyez Eyez
failure_reason: Creators went completely silent after Spring 2012. Raised 6x their goal but delivered nothing. Photo of team on beach in Thailand surfaced on Facebook then was deleted. Backers formed 'ZionKick' forum to organize against the scam.

name: SOAP Router
failure_reason: Project was exposed as likely scam from day one - lifted images from unrelated open source projects, no working prototype, impossible specs (Gigabit on chip that couldn't do it). Raised $400K total across platforms, delivered nothing.

name: Toasteroid
failure_reason: Connected to serial scam team (Nbition/Chiu brothers) behind Arist, ZNAPS, and Auxillite. None of these projects delivered products. Sketchfab profile linked to Nbition. No toasters shipped to backers despite reaching funding goal.

name: Lix 3D Pen
failure_reason: Analysts proved with physics that USB power (4.5W) was insufficient to melt filament as advertised (needed 24W like 3Doodler). Promo video was sped up dramatically. Years of delays, backers waited 2+ years. Company eventually went silent.

name: Sansaire Delta
failure_reason: Company shut down after relationship with production facility broke down and exhausted funding. Third CEO in one year announced closure. Despite original Sansaire's $823K success, Delta backers received nothing.

name: ZPM Espresso
failure_reason: After 3 years of delays, announced in January 2015 would not deliver machines or refund backers. COO left taking most of team. 300+ backers filed class action lawsuit. Technology eventually licensed to Decent Espresso.

name: La Fenice
failure_reason: World's first induction espresso machine raised 3x goal but failed to enter production. Project went silent after December 2017 update, over 7 years ago. No machines delivered to backers despite promising revolutionary technology.

name: QStoves ElectriQ
failure_reason: One year after raising $302K (30x goal), website went offline. Creator posted on Facebook claiming to be broke. Unable to ship remaining units or issue refunds as money was spent shipping early orders.

name: PicoBrew Pico C
failure_reason: Company entered receivership February 2020 after losing $500K/month with $15.2M debt. All assets liquidated. Machines dependent on cloud servers became non-functional (Error #7). Recipe PicoPaks discontinued.

name: FORT Magnetic Pillow Fort
failure_reason: Manufacturing costs doubled due to pandemic-era price increases in foam, magnets, and shipping. Sold at 50% discount to backers, couldn't break even. Closed May 2023, followed by CPSC recall in October 2023 citing magnets as choking hazards.

name: Darkest Dungeon: The Board Game
failure_reason: Shipping costs exceeded budget by $1.4M, manufacturing by $350K due to Ukraine war and inflation. Mythic Games demanded backers pay extra ($18-$69 for Wave 1). Company liquidated October 2024, Wave 2 never delivered.

name: HEL: The Last Saga
failure_reason: Originally expected June 2021, never completed after 4+ years. Mythic Games admitted project was 'excessively difficult, if not impossible' to complete. IP sold to CMON in January 2024, company liquidated October 2024.

name: Monsterpocalypse Board Game
failure_reason: Mythic Games' financial collapse prevented completion. Last official communication March 2023, nearly 2 years of silence. Company liquidated October 2024. Privateer Press (IP holder) only able to offer STL files as consolation.

name: SwitchLens
failure_reason: Apparent scam by Sneaki Design (China). Missed delivery promises (Nov 2024, then Feb/Mar 2025). No products delivered to any backers, creators went silent for 6+ months. BBB unable to locate business.

name: Lily Drone
failure_reason: Raised $34M in pre-orders for throw-and-go autonomous drone. R&D costs depleted funds before production. SF District Attorney sued for false advertising - promotional video used DJI Inspire drone, not Lily prototype. All pre-orders refunded.

name: Blocks Modular Smartwatch
failure_reason: Lost supplier ($1M invested) and software partner (acquired by Google) in 2016. Only 500 units shipped in 2017. Spent $2.8M on R&D by March 2018. Company entered liquidation August 2019 without fulfilling vast majority of backer rewards.

name: Skarp Laser Razor
failure_reason: Kickstarter suspended campaign at $4M for lacking working prototype. CNET found laser filament fragile, could only cut one hair at a time. Moved to Indiegogo, raised another $500K. As of 2019, still 'under development' with nothing shipped.

name: Kreyos Meteor
failure_reason: Promised waterproof smartwatch with 7-day battery and gesture control. Delivered 10 months late: 24-hour battery, couldn't tell time without Bluetooth, no gesture control, died in water. ODM Viewcooper took most of funds. Company ceased operations September 2014.

name: Plastc Card
failure_reason: Programmable card storing 20 credit cards raised $9M in pre-orders. Two investors withdrew $3.5M and $6.75M funding at eleventh hour. Filed Chapter 7 bankruptcy April 2017 without shipping single unit. Deleted all social media without offering refunds.

name: Coin Card
failure_reason: Digital wallet card hit $50K goal in 40 minutes. Shipped 2 years late in 2015 with only 52% transaction success rate. Apple Pay and chip cards made technology obsolete. Fitbit acquired assets, all services shut down February 28, 2017.

name: Doppler Labs Here One
failure_reason: Smart earbuds startup raised $50M+ total but sold only 25,000 units vs projected hundreds of thousands. Battery life of only 2 hours vs AirPods-competitive claims. Failed to raise Series C, shut down November 2017. Dolby acquired IP in 2018.

name: Kanoa Earbuds
failure_reason: Promised wireless earbuds to compete with AirPods at $300. Kept pushing ship dates - summer 2016 backers still waiting in 2017. Company shut down August 2017 without filling orders despite having raised additional VC funding.

name: Anki Vector
failure_reason: Despite raising $200M in VC and creating beloved robots (Cozmo, Vector), company shut down April 2019 when deal fell through at last minute. Cloud servers went offline, making robots non-functional. Digital Dream Labs acquired assets but struggled to maintain servers.

name: Jibo Robot
failure_reason: MIT researcher's social robot raised $3.7M on Indiegogo plus VC millions. Delayed from 2015 to 2017. International orders cancelled. Reviews compared it unfavorably to $20 Amazon Echo. Laid off staff, sold IP, servers shut down March 2019 rendering robots useless.

name: Kuri Robot
failure_reason: Mayfield Robotics (backed by Bosch) announced $700 home robot at CES 2017. Pre-orders opened but production never scaled. Company shut down July 2018 citing 'slow development of the consumer robotics category.' All pre-orders refunded.

name: Triton Artificial Gills
failure_reason: Claimed device could extract breathable oxygen from water for 45-minute underwater breathing. Experts proved physics impossible - would need to filter 90L water/minute. After investigation, admitted claims false, refunded all $900K to backers.

name: Fontus Self-Filling Water Bottle
failure_reason: Claimed solar-powered dehumidifier bottle producing 0.5L water per hour from air. Engineers calculated would need 250W solar panel with 1.5m surface. Creator's own documentation showed only 'one drop per minute.' Never delivered.

name: Solar Roadways
failure_reason: Indiegogo's most backed campaign ever. Promised to replace all US roads with solar panels featuring LEDs and heating. Engineers calculated costs would be many times federal budget. Test installations failed. Only parking lot demos ever built.

name: SpeedX Unicorn
failure_reason: Chinese startup raised ~$10M across campaigns for 'smart' road bikes. Original Leopard had quality issues. Unicorn campaign took hundreds of thousands more but bike never materialized. Company went silent, countless backers lost everything.

name: Raine One Electric Scooter
failure_reason: Melbourne-based startup raised $438K for 'giant leap forward' electric scooter. Ran over a year past delivery date before announcing they would stop development. No refunds offered. Hundreds of backers left with nothing.

name: Unicorn Electric Scooter
failure_reason: Flashy white electric scooter took pre-orders but was slow to deliver. Company sent notice in December 2019 that it had run out of money and couldn't deliver any scooters or issue refunds. All customers lost their money.

name: Elio Motors
failure_reason: 3-wheeled vehicle promised incredible fuel efficiency at $6,800 price. Raised $17M+ from 65,000+ reservations. Burned through investment in months on suspicious 'soft expenses' (executive paychecks). Vehicle never produced.

name: Coleco Chameleon
failure_reason: Retro gaming console exposed as scam. 'Prototype' at Toy Fair was SNES inside Atari Jaguar case. Second 'prototype' image showed CCTV capture card motherboard. Coleco withdrew branding, project cancelled. No working prototype ever existed.

name: NEEO Remote
failure_reason: Smart universal remote backed January 2015 with summer 2015 delivery. Didn't arrive until late 2017. Company acquired, no more software updates promised, servers only maintained minimum 24 months. Remote became useless brick.

name: Healbe GoBe
failure_reason: Russian company claimed wristband could measure calorie intake through skin glucose monitoring. Medical experts said technology impossible. Company lied about being SF-based, patents, and CES exhibition. Delivered product that didn't work as claimed.

name: Ritot Projection Watch
failure_reason: Watch claimed to project time on user's wrist. No working prototype, impossible physics (projector couldn't work in daylight), all images were renders. Ukrainian creators used fake names citing 'political unrest.' $1.4M raised, nothing delivered.

name: Scribble Pen
failure_reason: Pen claimed to scan any color and reproduce it in ink. Kickstarter cancelled after 3 days when backers raised concerns. Investigation found no trace of company or founders existing. Demo video was faked with post-production. No refunds.

name: Dragonfly Futurefon
failure_reason: 3-in-1 device (phone, tablet, laptop) supporting both Windows and Android with modular parts. Technology so complicated that creating even a prototype was impossible. Known as 'the biggest Indiegogo scam.' Backers got neither product nor refund.

name: Sense Smart Home Hub
failure_reason: Former Mozilla CTO Andreas Gal's smart home hub with AI and computer vision raised funding, then cancelled and refunded backers before development. Rare case of voluntary cancellation rather than failure to deliver.

name: Cicret Bracelet
failure_reason: Bracelet claimed to project touchscreen interface on arm. Like Ritot, physically impossible - projector can't work in daylight on skin. Raised money but kept pushing delivery dates. Eventually went silent. Known wrist projector scam.

name: Micro Drone 4.0
failure_reason: Campaign owner claimed production-ready drone 4.5+ years ago. Described as 'ongoing scam' with nothing but lies and excuses since. Over 8,000 backers waiting years for delivery with endless delays and empty promises.

name: Phantom Robotic Chessboard
failure_reason: Automatic chess board with moving pieces via magnetic system. Backed in August 2021 with February 2023 delivery estimate. As of 2025, still no product, no refund, no credible delivery timeline despite nearly 4 years passing.

name: Rocket eBike
failure_reason: Heavily promoted by Indiegogo despite clear evidence of no intention to deliver. Campaign ran usual playbook of delays and excuses. Described by backers as platform-endorsed scam. No bikes delivered.

name: Delfast eBike
failure_reason: California backer sued Delfast for non-delivery after Indiegogo campaign. Owner Daniel Tonkopi admitted in court he never intended to provide bikes to campaign backers. Court awarded plaintiff $2,198 plus costs.

name: Lockitron Smart Lock
failure_reason: Self-funded crowdfunding campaign for Bluetooth door lock raised $2.2M. Experienced significant delays delivering in substantial numbers. Eventually shipped thousands but ceased production. Became cautionary tale of hardware crowdfunding complexity.

name: X-tra Battery
failure_reason: Camera battery campaign exposed as likely fraud. 'CEO' Jeffery Parker found to be stock photo model from Hong Kong. Company had no verifiable existence. Campaign never intended to deliver products.

name: Hendo Hoverboard
failure_reason: Magnetic levitation hoverboard only worked on special copper surface. NYT noted creator had no skateboarding interest and called campaign 'basically a publicity stunt.' $10,000 price for hoverboard that couldn't work on normal surfaces.

name: Self-Balancing Scooter (Hovertrax)
failure_reason: Shane Chen's original self-balancing scooter design. While Chen delivered, Chinese knockoffs flooded market and caught fire. Over 500,000 units recalled by CPSC in 2016 due to battery fires. 23 recalls since affecting 1.1M+ units total.

name: Pressy
failure_reason: Android headphone jack button raised $695K but was immediately copied by Chinese manufacturers who shipped before Pressy. By time original shipped, knockoffs available for $2 vs Pressy's $17. Market destroyed by clones.

name: Ubuntu Edge
failure_reason: Canonical's convergent phone/desktop device sought $32M - largest crowdfunding goal ever at time. Despite raising $12.8M (Indiegogo record), fell $19M short. All money refunded. Phone never produced.

name: Nikola Labs Phone Case
failure_reason: Phone case claimed to 'recycle wasted energy' from phone radiation for 30% more battery. Technical analysis proved impossible - could recover 10% at absolute best under impossible conditions. Kickstarter failed to fund despite major PR push.

name: Moment Smartwatch
failure_reason: Smartwatch promising analog look with smart features. Repeated delays, then company went silent. Creator eventually admitted product couldn't be built as promised at the price point. Most backers received nothing.

name: Agent Smartwatch
failure_reason: Secret Labs raised $1M for smartwatch in 2013. Microsoft's .NET Micro Framework changes and manufacturing challenges caused endless delays. Four years later, still not shipped. Company eventually went quiet.

name: Trident Submarine
failure_reason: OpenROV's underwater drone raised $800K but struggled with production. Sofar Ocean acquired company, discontinued consumer products, and focused on B2B ocean monitoring. Consumer backers left with unfulfilled orders or limited support.

name: Zubr VR Camera
failure_reason: 360-degree VR camera for consumers promised affordable virtual reality content creation. VR market cooled significantly, company struggled with production costs. Project eventually abandoned with limited deliveries.

name: Airbag for Cyclists (Hovding)
failure_reason: Swedish airbag collar for cyclists raised funds but faced recalls. Some units deployed randomly without accidents. $299 price point limited adoption. Company struggled financially despite interesting technology.

name: Fidget Cube
failure_reason: While eventually delivered, $6.4M campaign faced massive counterfeiting. Chinese knockoffs available months before legitimate product shipped. Backers received items late while copies sold everywhere. Creators struggled with scale.

name: Znshine Solar E-Bike
failure_reason: Solar-powered electric bicycle claimed to charge while riding. Physics made claims dubious - solar panel on bike too small to provide meaningful charge. Multiple delivery delays, then silence from creators.

name: Snapchat Spectacles Clone - Weyes
failure_reason: Smart glasses copying Snapchat Spectacles concept at lower price. Struggled with hardware development complexity. Project went quiet after initial delays, no confirmed mass delivery to backers.

name: GlassUp Smart Glasses
failure_reason: Google Glass alternative raised funds for AR glasses projecting info to eye. Hardware complexity, component costs, and Google Glass's own struggles hurt market. Limited delivery, company pivoted away from consumer product.

name: Atlas Wristband
failure_reason: Fitness tracker claiming to auto-detect exercises raised $631K. Delivered late with mixed reviews on accuracy. Company struggled to compete with Fitbit/Apple, eventually shut down. Servers offline left devices with limited functionality.

name: Podo Stick-and-Shoot Camera
failure_reason: Bluetooth camera that sticks anywhere raised $1M. Delivered but struggled with smartphone camera improvements making product less compelling. Company released v2 but market moved on. Operations scaled down significantly.

name: WonderCube
failure_reason: 8-in-1 smartphone accessory cube (charger, stand, flashlight, etc.) raised $466K. Delivered very late with quality issues. Required design compromises made each function mediocre. Another 'Swiss army knife' gadget that tried to do too much.

name: Misfit Bolt Smart Bulb
failure_reason: Smart LED bulb syncing with Misfit wearables. Fossil acquired Misfit in 2015 for $260M, discontinued Bolt product line. Cloud services ended, leaving bulbs as dumb lights. Example of acquisition killing crowdfunded products.

name: Ring Video Doorbell
failure_reason: Now-famous Ring (acquired by Amazon for $1B) had rocky Kickstarter start. 'Doorbot' version delivered very late with significant issues. Many original backers didn't receive working units or waited years. Success came after Kickstarter, not through it.

name: Flyboard Air
failure_reason: Jet-powered personal flight board went viral with demos. Not crowdfunded but represents vaporware trend. Never commercially available despite years of promises. Franky Zapata attempted Channel crossing 2019, crashed. Military contracts but no consumer product.

name: POP Portable Power
failure_reason: Tiny emergency phone charger raised $139K. Apple refused to license Lightning connector, making iOS version impossible. Edison Junior refunded all money - rare case of full refund due to third-party blocking product completion.

name: Geek Wave
failure_reason: High-resolution portable music player raised $330K. Faced competition from smartphones with better DACs, LG V-series phones, and dedicated players. Development delays and market changes left product obsolete before shipping to most backers.

name: ONO 3D Printer
failure_reason: The $99 smartphone 3D printer raised $2.3M but failed to deliver working units. Renamed from OLO to ONO after trademark dispute. Community knew it was failure 1-2 years before official announcement. Concept physically couldn't work as advertised.

name: Robot Dragonfly (TechJect)
failure_reason: Insect-inspired micro drone raised $1.1M but faced impossible hardware challenges. Wings, transmission gears, servo system, and overheating chips all failed. Unable to bring robust product to market. Team eventually dissolved.

name: Yomee Yogurt Maker
failure_reason: Automatic yogurt maker raised funds but announced failure June 2023. Was NOT acquired by kitchen appliance company as hoped. Only small number of pre-production units offered in Hong Kong/Singapore. US backers received nothing.

name: Auxillite Smart Headphone Stand
failure_reason: Connected to serial scam team (Nbition/Chiu brothers) behind Arist, ZNAPS, and Toasteroid. Raised $250K for smart headphone stand with USB hub and charger. No products ever delivered despite successful funding.

name: Saygus V2 Phone
failure_reason: Utah company promised 'most advanced smartphone' with waterproofing, dual SD slots, fingerprint scanner. Delayed years past 2015 ship date. Shipped very few units that had major issues. Company still technically exists but product never properly delivered.

name: Turing Phone
failure_reason: Promised unhackable phone with 'Liquidmorphium' metal body. Pre-orders taken then OS switched from Android to Sailfish. Switched to even more expensive Turing Phone Cadenza. Company collapsed, moved to China, eventually shut down without delivering.

name: Comet Smartphone
failure_reason: Floating waterproof smartphone from the Comet Buoyant team. Despite raising $800K, phone never materialized. Team went quiet after repeated delays. Another case of impossible hardware promises from inexperienced creators.

name: Portal Smart Home Hub
failure_reason: Smart WiFi router with mesh networking and smart home hub raised $560K. Delivered late with numerous issues. Company pivoted to B2B, discontinued consumer support. Early adopters left with unsupported hardware.

name: PicoBrew Zymatic
failure_reason: Original PicoBrew product raised $661K. While initially successful, parent company eventually failed. February 2020 receivership with $15.2M debt. Cloud-dependent machines bricked (Error #7). All PicoBrew products now unsupported.

name: Cram Board Gaming Table
failure_reason: Gaming table with recessed playing surface, cup holders, and accessories raised $400K. Furniture shipping proved costly and complicated. Quality control issues, delays, and pandemic supply chain problems led to partial deliveries at best.

name: Remee Lucid Dreaming Mask
failure_reason: Sleep mask with LEDs to induce lucid dreaming raised $572K. Delivered, but users found it didn't work reliably for most people. Scientific basis questionable. Company eventually discontinued product and went quiet.

name: Muse Brain-Sensing Headband
failure_reason: EEG headband for meditation raised funds successfully and shipped. However, company struggled financially, required subscription for full features, and original backers felt misled about ongoing costs. Product evolved away from original promises.

name: SCiO Molecular Scanner
failure_reason: Pocket spectrometer claiming to analyze molecular composition of anything raised $2.7M. Shipped years late with severely limited functionality. Could only analyze pre-scanned materials in database. Real-world accuracy poor. Company pivoted to B2B.

name: SGNL Smart Strap
failure_reason: Watch strap using bone conduction to take calls with finger to ear raised $1.5M. Shipped very late with poor audio quality. Bluetooth connectivity issues. Bone conduction technology didn't work well in practice. Company went quiet.

name: Laundroid Folding Robot
failure_reason: Japanese company Seven Dreamers raised $60M for laundry-folding robot priced at $16,000. Promised 2019 release after years of demos. Company filed for bankruptcy April 2019. Robot was too slow (10+ minutes per item) and never commercially viable.

name: Essential Phone
failure_reason: Andy Rubin's (Android creator) startup raised $330M for modular smartphone. PH-1 phone had camera issues, modular accessories never materialized. Second phone cancelled. Company shut down February 2020. Showed even Android's creator couldn't succeed in hardware.
